raw_body:
arXiv:2509.16298v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Fuzzy implication functions are one of the most important operators used in the fuzzy logic framework. While their flexible definition allows for diverse families with distinct properties, this variety needs a deeper theoretical understanding of their structural relationships. In this work, we focus on the study of construction methods, which employ different techniques to generate new fuzzy implication functions from existing ones. Particularly, we generalize the $F$-chain-based construction, recently introduced by Mesiar et al. to extend a method for constructing aggregation functions to the context of fuzzy implication functions. Our generalization employs collections of fuzzy implication functions rather than single ones, and uses two different increasing functions instead of a unique $F$-chain. We analyze property preservation under this construction and establish sufficient conditions. Furthermore, we demonstrate that our generalized $F$-chain-based construction is a unifying framework for several existing methods. In particular, we show that various construction techniques, such as contraposition, aggregation, and generalized vertical/horizontal threshold methods, can be reformulated within our approach. This reveals structural similarities between seemingly distinct construction strategies and provides a cohesive perspective on fuzzy implication construction methods.
speedrun: A new study explores fuzzy implication functions, essential tools in fuzzy logic. It introduces a generalized construction method based on $F$-chains, which uses collections of functions instead of just one. This approach clarifies the relationships among various construction techniques, like contraposition and aggregation. Understanding these connections could improve the application of fuzzy logic in diverse fields, making it more efficient and effective.
why_it_matters: Researchers and practitioners in fuzzy logic could benefit from clearer methods, enhancing their work with more reliable tools.
This study suggests a shift towards unified frameworks in fuzzy logic, which could streamline research and applications across various sectors.

lenses.eli12: Fuzzy implication functions help computers make decisions based on uncertain information. This study shows how to create new functions using existing ones, similar to how chefs combine ingredients to make new recipes. Understanding these combinations could make technology smarter and more adaptable in everyday tasks.
lenses.pm: For product managers, this research highlights a new method to create fuzzy logic tools that could meet user needs more effectively. By using a generalized approach, teams might save time and resources when developing applications. This could lead to more innovative products that handle uncertainty better.
lenses.engineer: This paper presents a generalized $F$-chain-based construction method for fuzzy implication functions, employing multiple increasing functions instead of a single chain. It analyzes property preservation and establishes conditions for successful construction. This unifying framework could enhance the development of fuzzy logic applications by clarifying the relationships between different construction techniques.
